Summary

Identifies special floating-point values such as ±infinity, ±zero, and ±one in operands X and Y.

Parameters
M
parameter int

Mantissa width.

E
parameter int

Exponent width.

special_case
parameter int

Number of supported special cases (including non-special case).

Ports
X
input logic [E+ M:0]

First operand (in custom floating-point format).

Y
input logic [E+ M:0]

Second operand (in custom floating-point format).

X_special_case
output logic [$clog2(special_case)- 1:0]

Encoded identifier of the special case for operand X (0 = not special).

Y_special_case
output logic [$clog2(special_case)- 1:0]

Encoded identifier of the special case for operand Y (0 = not special).

Special case identifiers

Constant encoding of recognized special cases.

Variables
CASE_NONE
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_NONE = 0

No special case.

CASE_INF_P
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_INF_P = 1

Positive infinity.

CASE_INF_N
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_INF_N = 2

Negative infinity.

CASE_ZERO_P
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ZERO_P = 3

Positive zero.

CASE_ZERO_N
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ZERO_N = 4

Negative zero.

CASE_ONE_P
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ONE_P = 5

Positive one.

CASE_ONE_N
localparam logic [$clog2(
special_case
):0] CASE_ONE_N = 6

Negative one.

Detection of special cases

This section detects whether operand X is a special floating-point value, such as:

  • ±infinity: represented by all ones in the exponent and mantissa

  • ±zero: represented by all zeros in the exponent and mantissa

  • ±one: represented by an exponent of 1 and a mantissa of 0

Based on bit pattern analysis, the logic identifies the category of X and assigns a corresponding identifier code (X_special_case). This code is later used to determine if a special result must be returned by the floating-point adder.

The same logic is reused for operand Y without repeating the description.
